Despite significant research on global and national future pathways, there is a need for further exploration into the application of Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) and Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) to understand sub-national impacts on the electric power sector. This study employs the Global Change Analysis Model (GCAM-USA) to analyze how climate change mitigation and socioeconomic development interact in the U.S. electric power sector at the state level. We developed four scenarios covering different levels of decarbonization efforts and socioeconomic development. Our research findings reveal a prevailing trend towards a less carbon-intensive U.S. electric sector, propelled by an expanding presence of natural gas and renewable energies in the energy mix. Such capital turnover leads to a significant reduction of overall CO2 emissions from the electric sector, albeit at a higher lifetime cost in particularly eastern states. The mitigation efforts also lead to overall decreased water withdrawal and increased water consumption in the electric sector, however, disparities in state-level responses are observed. While population growth predominantly shapes electricity generation, unique state-level electrification potential yields indirect population-electricity dynamics. The spatially heterogeneous response suggests complex trade-offs associated with reconciling climate mitigation objectives with local electricity demand and resource con-straints. In sum, this research equips policymakers and stakeholders with invaluable insights to formulate mitigation strategies that align with the objective of the U.S. electric sector, both at a national and international level, while also catering to the unique characteristics of each state. ## Introduction The electric power sector is a significant contributor to climate change as it accounts for 38% of the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions globally [1] and 25% in the U.S. in 2021 [2]. Policies and strategies have been proposed and implemented at the international [3] and national levels [4] to reduce GHG emissions from the electric power sector. The Clean Air Act (CAA) serves as the primary basis for federal regulation of GHG emissions in the U.S., in which the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) works with states to reduce GHG emissions [5]. Despite several setbacks in climate mitigation initiatives [6,7], the U.S. rejoined the Paris Agreement and set an ambitious goal of economy-wide net-zero emissions by 2050, including a 65% reduction by 2030 [8]. Also, the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 will bring substantial changes to the power sector, aligning with climate goals and reinforcing energy security. This legislation will reshape energy policies, promoting adaptations for economic stability, inflation reduction, and sector resilience. These changes will lead to transformative measures, prioritizing sustainable energy practices while addressing both eco- nomic and environmental concerns [4]. The success of achieving national climate mitigation targets relies heavily on the implementation of effective sub-national climate actions [9]. States employ a variety of programs to reduce their GHG emissions, such as climate action plans, mandatory GHG reporting, voluntary GHG reporting, and reduction programs [10]. Significant progress has already been made at the state level, with the current state and local GHG actions projected to reduce economy-wide emissions by 25% below the 2005 level by 2030 [9]. As of 2022, 25 states and territories have set GHG reduction targets, with some committing to achieving 100% clean energy goals by 2050 or earlier [11] through renewable portfolio standards, energy efficiency standards, and carbon pricing mechanisms. Therefore, developing sub-national strategies for the power sector in alignment with a national mitigation target is a complex task, particularly when socioeconomic factors are expected to shift and impact power demand. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has devel-oped Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) and Shared So-cioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) to explore different combinations of greenhouse gas emissions and socioeconomic trends [13,14]. Combining these scenarios allows for the examination of potential barriers and opportunities for climate mitigation and adaptation across a wide range of plausible futures. Additionally, the integrated assessment modeling (IAM) approach is widely employed to evaluate the viability of mitiga-tion strategies. IAMs have been extensively utilized in a large body of research to evaluate the effectiveness of various mitigation strategies across scales [15-19]. These models are particularly relevant for poli-cymakers as they provide insights into the trade-offs between different mitigation strategies and the potential costs and benefits associated with their implementation. DeAngelo et al. [20] analyzed 177 global IAM scenarios with different warming levels and found that achieving 1.5 °C resulted in lower energy use, earlier net zero, and less electrification because of the shorter transition time, while greater than 2 °C produced more residual emissions and bioenergy use with regional disparities. McJeon et al. [21] found that with a below 2 °C global temperature objective, global coal consumption decreases by mid-century, and nat-ural gas consumption increases when carbon capture and storage is available and decreases when it is not. Zapata et al. [22] analyzed the impact of climate change on the energy system focusing on four renewable sources and found that while there were small climate im-pacts on renewable primary energy use globally, these impacts led to a decrease in fossil fuel use due to increase in renewables use for most regions, especially in North America. Fragkos et al. [23] explored low-emission scenarios for eleven countries and concluded that emission reductions are achieved through the uptake of renewable energy, energy efficiency improvements, and electrification of energy services. More-over, Khan et al. [24] investigated the impacts of temperature changes on the electricity sector within a scenario aligned with SSP2 and RCP 8.5. They found that Cooling Degree Hours (CDH) increased while Heating Degree Hours (HDH) decreased from 2015 to 2100, with sig-nificant state-level variations. For example, annual mean CDH increased by 30% in Arizona to 170% in Wyoming, and mean HDH decreased by 13% in Florida to 45% in Arizona. Such variations highlight the het-erogeneous impacts of temperature changes on electric sector capacity and investment requirements across the U.S. Burleyson et al. [25] assessed building electricity consumption responses in the western U.S. using two models, BEND and GCAM-USA, under combinations of sce-narios for radiative forcing (RCP4.5 & 8.5) and population change (SSP3 & 5). Despite structural differences, both models demonstrated similar responses, emphasizing the more significant impact of population change and also identified an increase in total building electricity con-sumption under the RCP8.5 scenario in certain states, while others remained largely unaffected. Kebede et al. [26] explored climate change impacts by integrating a global scenario framework, RCP-SSP-SPA, assessing how global pathways manifest as sub-national impacts in three deltas across West Africa and South Asia. Their integrated multi-scale (combined top-down and bottom-up) hybrid scenario approach, combining expert-based and participatory (joint expert-stakeholder) methods, emphasizes the significance of such approaches in address-ing uncertainty in adaptation decision-making, underlining its trans-ferability to other sub-national socio-ecological settings with multi-scale challenges. While prior research primarily concentrated on evaluating the viability and consequences of diverse low-emission trajectories, like those outlined in the RCPs, for meeting global and national climate objectives, it is equally imperative to investigate how the RCP-SSP pathways on a global scale manifest as impacts on electricity sectors at the sub-national level. While sub-national actions have been shown to be effective in reducing emissions and supporting U.S. national efforts [9, 12], there are fewer subnational-level studies that analyze how top-down policies or targets impact the electric power sector at the state level. Hence, our study seeks to enhance comprehension of the interre- lation between top-down climate change mitigation and socioeconomic progress (e.g., population and GDP) in shaping the U.S. electric power sector at the state level. By analyzing the potential impact of different socioeconomic pathways on state level electricity and environmental consequences (e.g., water, CO2 emissions, etc.), we can gain insights into aligning sub-national mitigation strategies in the electricity sector with national and global mitigation goals. Methods We used the global change analysis model, USA version (GCAM-USA), which is an integrated assessment model developed to explore the dynamics of the coupled human-earth system and its response to global changes [27,28]. GCAM consists of five interconnected systems (energy, water, agriculture and land use, economy, and climate), running in 5-year intervals until 2100 [28]. GCAM has been widely employed in numerous studies to evaluate the potential impacts of different policy assumptions and socioeconomic factors on future conditions at national and international scales, such as the 4th and 5th IPCC assessment reports [14,29-32]. GCAM employs external data files containing assumptions about key drivers such as population, GDP, policies, etc., to estimate their implications on crucial outputs like GHG emissions, energy production, and water consumption. GCAM simulates the substitution of high-carbon technologies with low-carbon alternatives based on factors like costs, emissions constraints, and carbon prices. It can also simulate various mitigation actions, including carbon capture, electric vehicles, and more (Table S1). The energy system framework of GCAM encompasses resource production, energy transformation, final energy carriers, and end-use sectors (Fig. S1). The GCAM-USA model provides higher spatial detail, including 50 states plus the District of Columbia. The electricity generation sector within GCAM-USA offers greater detail compared to GCAM, including sub-annual load profiles, US-specific power sector technology costs, state-specific retirements of coal and nuclear plants, and grid region trading. This enables GCAM-USA to investigate mitigation and adaptation of the energy system at the state level, such as exploring state-level power sector capacity expansion pathways [33], electric vehicle deployment for U.S. [34], and environmental co-benefits of low-carbon pathways with state-level resolution [35]. A detailed description of water and power sector modeling in GCAM-USA is available in the Supplementary Material. In this study, we employed GCAM-USA v5.4 and explored four future scenarios for the U.S. that are in line with the global RCPs and SSPs pathways (Table 1). We selected RCP2.6, RCP6.0, SSP3, and SSP5 and created four scenarios by combining the RCPs and SSPs. The RCP-SSP scenarios are relevant in the global context. Our 'RCP-SSP equivalent' scenarios suggest that the conditions of these RCP-SSP scenarios in the U.S. context correspond to those outlined in the global scenarios. In the U.S. context, this translates to a 58% of CO2 emission reduction in 2050 relative to 2015 and zero emission around 2070. Conversely, RCP6.0 depicts a stabilization scenario where GHG emissions peak around 2080, leading to a continuous warming trend and a 3–4 °C global temperature increase by 2100 [30]. In the U.S. context, this is described by continuous growth in CO2 emissions with a peak projected to occur around the year 2095. It is worth noting that RCP6.0 is the reference scenario in GCAM. Incorporating both scenarios enables us to assess a wider array of potential outcomes. SSP3 embodies a "regional rivalry" scenario characterized by high challenges in mitigation and adaptation, prioritizing national and regional security over global cooperation. Industrialized countries experience slow economic growth and low population growth while developing countries face high population growth. In the U.S. context, population growth is projected to be low, with a slight decrease in the second half of the century. Population stabilizes around 267.5 million in 2100 (Fig. S2). In contrast, SSP5 portrays a "Fossil fuel Development" scenario with high challenges in mitigation but low challenges in adaptation. It envisions rapid global economic growth and the exploitation of fossil fuel resources to achieve socioeconomic development goals [36,37]. In the U.S. context, under the SSP5 scenario, the population is projected to steadily increase to 674.2 million by 2100 (Fig. S2). While a warming climate (i.e., RCP6.0) contributes to an increase in climate extremes (e.g., droughts, floods, wildfires, etc.), delving into their intricate details surpasses the capacity of an aggregated model like GCAM-USA. ## Results and discussion As shown in Fig. 1, electricity demand is projected to increase under High population/GDP scenarios, with greater increases when mitigation is present. Mitigation leads to more end-use electrification, particularly in the industry and transportation sectors (Fig. S3) because of the aggressive push towards economy-wide decarbonization. In the Low population/GDP scenarios, a slight decrease in the second half of the century is observed, following the trajectories of the population in these scenarios (Fig. S2). This shows that electricity demand is strongly influenced by population trajectory. The share of renewables in the U.S. electric generation mix has been increasing in recent years, growing from 9.4% to 21.5% between 2000 and 2022 [38], and this trend is expected to continue due to ongoing advancements in renewable energy technologies, decreasing costs of renewables, growing public and political support for clean energy, and the implementation of state and federal policies (i.e., New Source and Performance Standards, the Investment Tax Credit, and the Production Tax credit) in incentivizing renewable energy (including wind, solar, biomass, geothermal, and hydro) deployment. Our results (Fig. 1) confirm a general growth in low-carbon energy sources' shares (including renewables and nuclear) with a more pronounced increase under low emission scenarios. In the reference scenarios with low and high population/GDP, we observe a 122 % and 573 % increase from 2020 to 2100, respectively. In the low emission scenarios with low and high population/GDP, the increase is even more substantial, reaching 313 % and an impressive 1120 %, respectively. The share of renewables and fossil fuels with carbon capture and storage (CCS) also increases substantially in low emission scenarios. This highlights the necessity of CCS for achieving aggressive mitigation targets by 2100. Notably, without mitigation, the share of natural gas increases by 79 % and 330 % from 2020 to 2100 with low and high population/GDP, respectively. This shows that in the absence of mitigation efforts, this cleaner and cheaper source of fuel is expected to meet most of the growing demand for electricity. Nevertheless, it's crucial to acknowledge that such a significant surge in the natural gas share could lead to concerns regarding the sustainability of natural gas resources and the potential for their depletion. This, in turn, could result in higher prices and consequential environmental impacts. Contrary to the general increasing trend in electricity generation across all scenarios, the implications on water withdrawals and con- sumption for the electricity sector are more complex. Fig. 2a shows that electric sector water withdrawals generally decrease across scenarios, and a drastic decline occurs before 2050 for low emission scenarios: -70 to -67% decrease from 2020 to 2050 for reference scenarios and -93 to -90% for low emission scenarios, respectively. The retirement of coal power plants and more water-efficient generation technologies are the primary contributors to the decline (Fig. S4.a). Other factors, such as increased use of non-water dependent cooling technologies and a shift towards renewable energy sources, also decreased overall water with- drawals [39]. It is worth noting that a slight increase is observed after 2050 for low emission scenarios, mainly attributed to the increasing trend in electricity generation driven by end-use electrification and decarbonization efforts (e.g., CCS). The declining trend of water withdrawal in the electricity sector is also substantiated by historical data from 1990 to 2015 [40]. Texas, however, presented an exception with a modest increase of 1.14%. The trend of electric sector water consumption varies significantly among the different scenarios (Fig. S6.a). In the reference scenarios, a decline of -35 % is observed in the first half, followed by an increase in the high population/GDP scenario. Gradual decline throughout the century is observed in the low population/GDP scenario. In contrast, under the low emission scenarios, water consumption declines for the first 30 years, then increases moderately and substantially in the low population/GDP scenario and high population/GDP scenario, respec- tively. The retirement of coal power plants and the uptake of less water- dependent cooling technologies (Fig. S4.b) are the main drivers behind the reduction before the 2030s. The increase in the second half is largely driven by growing electricity generation for end-use electrification. The rate of electricity generation growth to meet the demand outpaces the rate of decline from capital turnover. Notably, among all the scenarios, under the low emission scenario, water consumption reaches its peak across all states, and Texas stands out for having the most substantial water usage (Fig. S6.b). This complex dynamic among water, energy, and mitigation highlights the need for a holistic view that considers the benefits and trade-offs for decarbonizing the energy system at the state level. A low value close to zero (whether positive or negative) indicates that population growth is the primary driver behind increases in electricity generation. A larger positive value suggests that factors other than population are influencing the observed growth of electricity generation. As can be seen in Fig. 3, the results illustrate heterogeneous responses at the state level. The largest electricity user in most states is the building sector (Fig. S8), whose electricity demand is a direct reflection of population. Therefore, the elasticity indicators for most states are close to 0 and electricity generation grows with population growth. However, in the case of Wyoming, the elasticity indicator is significantly greater than 0.3. This is attributed to Wyoming's relatively small population base [41] and the industry sector being the most significant consumer of electricity within the state (Fig. S8). End-use electrification of the industry sector leads to the increase in electricity generation in Wyoming, a pattern not notably swayed by the state's population dynamics. Similarly, Nebraska's electricity generation is influenced by various factors beyond population growth. Nebraska exhibits high per capita electricity consumption, an energy-intensive industrial sector, and significant energy demands resulting from extreme weather conditions, including hot summers and harsh winters [42]. These combined factors create Nebraska's energy profile, highlighting that population is just one aspect of its multifaceted energy generation equation. For Montana, the surge in electricity generation is influenced by the end-use electrification of the transportation sector. The state has the highest number of vehicles per person [43], and electrification of the transportation sector will lead to greater demand for electricity. Additionally, both West Virginia and Utah are net suppliers of electricity to the regional grid and are among the top states in interstate transfers of electricity [44,45]. Likewise, North Dakota follows a similar pattern, with about two-thirds of its generated power being transmitted to other states and Canada through the regional electric grid [46]. As a result, the increase in electricity generation in West Virginia, Utah, and North Dakota is not solely influenced by their respective populations but is also significantly impacted by electricity transfers to neighboring regions. These observations underscore the notion that while population growth contributes to the escalating electricity demand across the U.S., the pivotal driving factor tends to differ from one state to another. We also examined the environmental consequences of mitigation and socioeconomic development. Fig. 4 illustrates the projected changes in CO2 intensity (million metric tons/EJ) from electricity generation relative to 2015 for each state. CO2 intensity refers to the ratio of CO2 emissions from the electricity sector to the amount of electricity generated. As can be observed, the CO2 intensity of electricity generation is expected to decrease over time across all scenarios. However, the rate and pattern of such decrease are heterogeneous across all states. Renewable energies are prioritized in states in the Mountain (i. e., Wyoming), Midwest (i.e., Missouri), and South (i.e., Texas) regions and limited in the Atlantic (i.e., New York) and Pacific regions (i.e., Washington). States characterized by a significant proportion of coal- fired electricity generation, such as Wyoming and West Virginia, are projected to experience significant reductions in the CO2 intensity of their electricity generation. This trend is especially prominent when considering scenarios characterized by low emissions. Anticipated de- clines of approximately -233 and -240 million metric tons/EJ on average by 2080, in comparison to the year 2015, are attributed to the combined impact of retiring coal-fired power generation and the adop- tion of renewable energy sources. Conversely, states like South Dakota, which already embrace a substantial share of renewable energy (with over 80% of its electricity generated from renewables in 2021 [47]), face a more constrained potential for further enhancing their CO2 in- tensity performance. Projections suggest a comparatively narrower scope for improvement, with an average anticipated reduction of approximately -50 million metric tons/EJ by 2080 relative to the reference year of 2015, as outlined in scenarios with low emissions. Texas, on the other hand, exhibits an intriguing dynamic, while it ex- periences a significant reduction in CO2 intensity, with an average reduction of roughly -102 million metric tons/EJ by 2080, it also faces a notable increase in water withdrawal. This dual trend underscores the intricate challenges and trade-offs involved in transitioning to a low-carbon energy framework. It exemplifies how states must carefully balance environmental considerations, such as CO2 emissions, with other critical resources like water. These contrasting outcomes empha- size the distinct capacities of each state to navigate the complex tran- sition toward a low-carbon energy framework. We also investigated the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) under low emission scenarios in comparison to that of under the "Stated Pol- icies" and the "Announced Pledges" [48] (Fig. 5a). LCOE is a measure of the average net present cost of electricity generation for a generator over its lifetime [49]. It includes initial capital investment, operational and maintenance costs, and expected energy output. It has been widely used to compare various forms of electricity production for investment de- cisions. The "Stated Policies" scenario assumes current policies and implementing measures will continue without additional efforts, considering adopted policies, proposals, and yet-to-be-developed mea- sures. In contrast, the "Announced Pledges" scenario assumes the suc- cessful implementation of government commitments and targets under the Paris Agreement, including Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and net zero goals [48]. Conclusion Previous research has primarily centered on global and national climate objectives, with less emphasis on how RCP-SSP pathways influence the sub-national electricity sector. Our study addresses this gap by analyzing how climate change mitigation and socioeconomic development interact in the U.S. electric power sector at the state level. The analysis delves into the effects on electricity generation, electricity water withdrawal and consumption, CO2 intensity, and levelized cost of electricity (LOCE) at the state level. The underlying mechanisms that drive the heterogeneous responses at the state level are also examined. Several key conclusions can be drawn from this study. First, expanding end-use electrification in the building and industry sectors not only facilitates the attainment of mitigation objectives but also catalyzes a surge in electricity generation. This surge is enabled by a rapid growth of natural gas utilization in conjunction with renewable energy sources. Population growth is the primary catalyst behind the surges in most states. In states where the industry sector is the dominant end-user, the interplay between population and electricity dynamics is comparatively subdued. This underscores the importance of understanding end-use electricity for gauging future electricity demand, considering diverse patterns and electrification potential at the state level. Second, sustainable electricity generation requires balancing multiple considerations, including emissions, environmental conservation, and economic viability [53]. Our low emission scenarios notably reduce water withdrawals, aligning with resource conservation. This shift is propelled by technological advancements, more efficient water cooling, and the embrace of renewable energy sources. Despite the decrease in water withdrawals, water consumption increases. Diverse impacts of mitigation on electricity water use are evident, resulting in increased water withdrawals for certain states (i.e., Texas) while causing reductions for others (i.e., Florida). In our low emission scenarios, renewable energies are prioritized in states in the Mountain (i.e., Wyoming), Midwest (i.e., Missouri), and South (i.e., Texas) regions and limited in the Atlantic (i.e., New York) and Pacific regions (i.e., Washington). Substantial CO2 reduction is achieved, though accompanied by an increased Levelized Cost of Electricity (LCOE), particularly in the eastern states. However, the combined efforts still fall short of achieving the collective commitments under the Paris Agreement. This underscores the importance of managing the balance between water resources, mitigation efforts, and economic feasibility at the state level. Overall, this research underscores the complexity of reconciling climate mitigation objectives with local electricity demand and resource constraints. It highlights the need for nuanced, state-specific strategies that balance emissions reduction, electricity demand, and water usage. Implications of climate change mitigation and socioeconomic development on the U.S. electric power sector
Fatemeh Ganji, Lu Liu *, Shanna Fellows
Civil, Construction and Environmental Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA, USA
ARTICLE INFO --- *Keywords:* Climate change Energy sector Climate change mitigation GCAM U.S. state
A B S T R A C T

Climate change poses a global challenge, and the electric power sector, as a major greenhouse gas contributor, plays a central role in tackling and curbing its effects. Despite significant research on global and national future pathways, there is a need for further exploration into the application of Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) and Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) to understand sub-national impacts on the electric power sector. This study employs the Global Change Analysis Model (GCAM-USA) to analyze how climate change mitigation and socioeconomic development interact in the U.S. electric power sector at the state level. We developed four scenarios covering different levels of decarbonization efforts and socioeconomic development. Our research findings reveal a prevailing trend towards a less carbon-intensive U.S. electric sector, propelled by an expanding presence of natural gas and renewable energies in the energy mix. Such capital turnover leads to a significant reduction of overall CO2 emissions from the electric sector, albeit at a higher lifetime cost in particularly eastern states. The mitigation efforts also lead to overall decreased water withdrawal and increased water consumption in the electric sector, however, disparities in state-level responses are observed. While population growth predominantly shapes electricity generation, unique state-level electrification potential yields indirect population-electricity dynamics. The spatially heterogeneous response suggests complex trade-offs associated with reconciling climate mitigation objectives with local electricity demand and resource con-straints. In sum, this research equips policymakers and stakeholders with invaluable insights to formulate mitigation strategies that align with the objective of the U.S. electric sector, both at a national and international level, while also catering to the unique characteristics of each state.

## Introduction The electric power sector is a significant contributor to climate change as it accounts for 38% of the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions globally [1] and 25% in the U.S. in 2021 [2]. Policies and strategies have been proposed and implemented at the international [3] and national levels [4] to reduce GHG emissions from the electric power sector. The Clean Air Act (CAA) serves as the primary basis for federal regulation of GHG emissions in the U.S., in which the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) works with states to reduce GHG emissions [5]. Despite several setbacks in climate mitigation initiatives [6,7], the U.S. rejoined the Paris Agreement and set an ambitious goal of economy-wide net-zero emissions by 2050, including a 65% reduction by 2030 [8]. Also, the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 will bring substantial changes to the power sector, aligning with climate goals and reinforcing energy security. This legislation will reshape energy policies,

promoting adaptations for economic stability, inflation reduction, and sector resilience. These changes will lead to transformative measures, prioritizing sustainable energy practices while addressing both eco- nomic and environmental concerns [4].

The success of achieving national climate mitigation targets relies heavily on the implementation of effective sub-national climate actions [9]. States employ a variety of programs to reduce their GHG emissions, such as climate action plans, mandatory GHG reporting, voluntary GHG reporting, and reduction programs [10]. Significant progress has already been made at the state level, with the current state and local GHG actions projected to reduce economy-wide emissions by 25% below the 2005 level by 2030 [9]. As of 2022, 25 states and territories have set GHG reduction targets, with some committing to achieving 100% clean energy goals by 2050 or earlier [11] through renewable portfolio standards, energy efficiency standards, and carbon pricing mechanisms. While decarbonizing the energy systems entails higher costs for most

Therefore, developing sub-national strategies for the power sector in alignment with a national mitigation target is a complex task, particularly when socioeconomic factors are expected to shift and impact power demand.

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has devel-oped Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) and Shared So-cioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) to explore different combinations of greenhouse gas emissions and socioeconomic trends [13,14]. Combining these scenarios allows for the examination of potential barriers and opportunities for climate mitigation and adaptation across a wide range of plausible futures. Additionally, the integrated assessment modeling (IAM) approach is widely employed to evaluate the viability of mitiga-tion strategies. IAMs have been extensively utilized in a large body of research to evaluate the effectiveness of various mitigation strategies across scales [15-19]. These models are particularly relevant for poli-cymakers as they provide insights into the trade-offs between different mitigation strategies and the potential costs and benefits associated with their implementation. DeAngelo et al. [20] analyzed 177 global IAM scenarios with different warming levels and found that achieving 1.5 °C resulted in lower energy use, earlier net zero, and less electrification because of the shorter transition time, while greater than 2 °C produced more residual emissions and bioenergy use with regional disparities. McJeon et al. [21] found that with a below 2 °C global temperature objective, global coal consumption decreases by mid-century, and nat-ural gas consumption increases when carbon capture and storage is available and decreases when it is not. Zapata et al. [22] analyzed the impact of climate change on the energy system focusing on four renewable sources and found that while there were small climate im-pacts on renewable primary energy use globally, these impacts led to a decrease in fossil fuel use due to increase in renewables use for most regions, especially in North America. Fragkos et al. [23] explored low-emission scenarios for eleven countries and concluded that emission reductions are achieved through the uptake of renewable energy, energy efficiency improvements, and electrification of energy services. More-over, Khan et al. [24] investigated the impacts of temperature changes on the electricity sector within a scenario aligned with SSP2 and RCP 8.5. They found that Cooling Degree Hours (CDH) increased while Heating Degree Hours (HDH) decreased from 2015 to 2100, with sig-nificant state-level variations. For example, annual mean CDH increased by 30% in Arizona to 170% in Wyoming, and mean HDH decreased by 13% in Florida to 45% in Arizona. Such variations highlight the het-erogeneous impacts of temperature changes on electric sector capacity and investment requirements across the U.S. Burleyson et al. [25] assessed building electricity consumption responses in the western U.S. using two models, BEND and GCAM-USA, under combinations of sce-narios for radiative forcing (RCP4.5 & 8.5) and population change (SSP3 & 5). Despite structural differences, both models demonstrated similar responses, emphasizing the more significant impact of population change and also identified an increase in total building electricity con-sumption under the RCP8.5 scenario in certain states, while others remained largely unaffected. Kebede et al. [26] explored climate change impacts by integrating a global scenario framework, RCP-SSP-SPA, assessing how global pathways manifest as sub-national impacts in three deltas across West Africa and South Asia. Their integrated multi-scale (combined top-down and bottom-up) hybrid scenario approach, combining expert-based and participatory (joint expert-stakeholder) methods, emphasizes the significance of such approaches in address-ing uncertainty in adaptation decision-making, underlining its trans-ferability to other sub-national socio-ecological settings with multi-scale challenges.
While prior research primarily concentrated on evaluating the viability and consequences of diverse low-emission trajectories, like those outlined in the RCPs, for meeting global and national climate

objectives, it is equally imperative to investigate how the RCP-SSP pathways on a global scale manifest as impacts on electricity sectors at the sub-national level. While sub-national actions have been shown to be effective in reducing emissions and supporting U.S. national efforts [9, 12], there are fewer subnational-level studies that analyze how top-down policies or targets impact the electric power sector at the state level. Hence, our study seeks to enhance comprehension of the interre- lation between top-down climate change mitigation and socioeconomic progress (e.g., population and GDP) in shaping the U.S. electric power sector at the state level. By analyzing the potential impact of different socioeconomic pathways on state level electricity and environmental consequences (e.g., water, CO2 emissions, etc.), we can gain insights into aligning sub-national mitigation strategies in the electricity sector with national and global mitigation goals.

Methods We used the global change analysis model, USA version (GCAM-USA), which is an integrated assessment model developed to explore the dynamics of the coupled human-earth system and its response to global changes [27,28]. GCAM consists of five interconnected systems (energy, water, agriculture and land use, economy, and climate), running in 5-year intervals until 2100 [28]. GCAM has been widely employed in numerous studies to evaluate the potential impacts of different policy assumptions and socioeconomic factors on future conditions at national and international scales, such as the 4th and 5th IPCC assessment reports [14,29-32]. GCAM employs external data files containing assumptions about key drivers such as population, GDP, policies, etc., to estimate their implications on crucial outputs like GHG emissions, energy production, and water consumption. GCAM simulates the substitution of high-carbon technologies with low-carbon alternatives based on factors like costs, emissions constraints, and carbon prices. It can also simulate various mitigation actions, including carbon capture, electric vehicles, and more (Table S1). The energy system framework of GCAM encompasses resource production, energy transformation, final energy carriers, and end-use sectors (Fig. S1). The GCAM-USA model provides higher spatial detail, including 50 states plus the District of Columbia. The electricity generation sector within GCAM-USA offers greater detail compared to GCAM, including sub-annual load profiles, US-specific power sector technology costs, state-specific retirements of coal and nuclear plants, and grid region trading. This enables GCAM-USA to investigate mitigation and adaptation of the energy system at the state level, such as exploring state-level power sector capacity expansion pathways [33], electric vehicle deployment for U.S. [34], and environmental co-benefits of low-carbon pathways with state-level resolution [35]. A detailed description of water and power sector modeling in GCAM-USA is available in the Supplementary Material.

In this study, we employed GCAM-USA v5.4 and explored four future scenarios for the U.S. that are in line with the global RCPs and SSPs pathways (Table 1). We selected RCP2.6, RCP6.0, SSP3, and SSP5 and created four scenarios by combining the RCPs and SSPs. The RCP-SSP scenarios are relevant in the global context. Our 'RCP-SSP equivalent' scenarios suggest that the conditions of these RCP-SSP scenarios in the U.S. context correspond to those outlined in the global scenarios. ## Results and discussion As shown in Fig. 1, electricity demand is projected to increase under High population/GDP scenarios, with greater increases when mitigation is present. Mitigation leads to more end-use electrification, particularly in the industry and transportation sectors (Fig. S3) because of the aggressive push towards economy-wide decarbonization. In the Low population/GDP scenarios, a slight decrease in the second half of the century is observed, following the trajectories of the population in these scenarios (Fig. S2). This shows that electricity demand is strongly influenced by population trajectory.

The share of renewables in the U.S. electric generation mix has been increasing in recent years, growing from 9.4% to 21.5% between 2000 and 2022 [38], and this trend is expected to continue due to ongoing

advancements in renewable energy technologies, decreasing costs of renewables, growing public and political support for clean energy, and the implementation of state and federal policies (i.e., New Source and Performance Standards, the Investment Tax Credit, and the Production Tax credit) in incentivizing renewable energy (including wind, solar, biomass, geothermal, and hydro) deployment. Our results (Fig. 1) confirm a general growth in low-carbon energy sources' shares (including renewables and nuclear) with a more pronounced increase under low emission scenarios. In the reference scenarios with low and high population/GDP, we observe a 122 % and 573 % increase from 2020 to 2100, respectively. In the low emission scenarios with low and high population/GDP, the increase is even more substantial, reaching 313 % and an impressive 1120 %, respectively. The share of renewables and fossil fuels with carbon capture and storage (CCS) also increases substantially in low emission scenarios. This highlights the necessity of CCS for achieving aggressive mitigation targets by 2100. Notably, without mitigation, the share of natural gas increases by 79 % and 330 % from 2020 to 2100 with low and high population/GDP, respectively. This shows that in the absence of mitigation efforts, this cleaner and cheaper source of fuel is expected to meet most of the growing demand for electricity. Nevertheless, it's crucial to acknowledge that such a significant surge in the natural gas share could lead to concerns regarding the sustainability of natural gas resources and the potential for their depletion. This, in turn, could result in higher prices and consequential environmental impacts.

Contrary to the general increasing trend in electricity generation across all scenarios, the implications on water withdrawals and con- sumption for the electricity sector are more complex. Fig. 2a shows that electric sector water withdrawals generally decrease across scenarios, and a drastic decline occurs before 2050 for low emission scenarios: -70 to -67% decrease from 2020 to 2050 for reference scenarios and -93 to -90% for low emission scenarios, respectively. The retirement of coal power plants and more water-efficient generation technologies are the primary contributors to the decline (Fig. S4.a). Other factors, such as increased use of non-water dependent cooling technologies and a shift towards renewable energy sources, also decreased overall water with- drawals [39]. It is worth noting that a slight increase is observed after 2050 for low emission scenarios, mainly attributed to the increasing trend in electricity generation driven by end-use electrification and decarbonization efforts (e.g., CCS). The trend of electric sector water consumption varies significantly among the different scenarios (Fig. S6.a). In the reference scenarios, a decline of -35 % is observed in the first half, followed by an increase in the high population/GDP scenario. Gradual decline throughout the century is observed in the low population/GDP scenario. In contrast, under the low emission scenarios, water consumption declines for the

first 30 years, then increases moderately and substantially in the low population/GDP scenario and high population/GDP scenario, respec- tively. The retirement of coal power plants and the uptake of less water- dependent cooling technologies (Fig. S4.b) are the main drivers behind the reduction before the 2030s. The increase in the second half is largely driven by growing electricity generation for end-use electrification. The rate of electricity generation growth to meet the demand outpaces the rate of decline from capital turnover. Notably, among all the scenarios, under the low emission scenario, water consumption reaches its peak across all states, and Texas stands out for having the most substantial water usage (Fig. S6.b). This complex dynamic among water, energy, and mitigation highlights the need for a holistic view that considers the benefits and trade-offs for decarbonizing the energy system at the state level.

As can be seen in Fig. 3, the results illustrate heterogeneous responses at the state level. The largest electricity user in most states is the building sector (Fig. S8), whose electricity demand is a direct reflection of population. Therefore, the elasticity indicators for most states are close to 0 and electricity generation grows with population growth. However, in the case of Wyoming, the elasticity indicator is significantly greater than 0.3. This is attributed to Wyoming's relatively small population base [41] and the industry sector being the most significant consumer of electricity within the state (Fig. S8). End-use electrification of the industry sector leads to the increase in electricity generation in Wyoming, a pattern not notably swayed by the state's population dynamics. Similarly, Nebraska's electricity generation is influenced by various factors beyond population growth. Nebraska exhibits high per capita electricity consumption, an energy-intensive industrial sector, and significant energy demands resulting from extreme weather conditions, including hot summers and harsh winters [42]. These combined factors create Nebraska's energy profile, highlighting that population is just one aspect of its multifaceted energy generation equation. For Montana, the surge in electricity generation is influenced by the end-use electrification of the transportation sector. The state has the highest number of vehicles per person [43], and electrification of the transportation sector will lead to greater demand for electricity. Additionally, both West Virginia and Utah are net suppliers of electricity to the regional grid and are among the top states in interstate transfers of electricity [44,45]. Likewise, North Dakota follows a similar pattern, with about two-thirds of its generated power being transmitted to other states and Canada through the regional electric grid [46]. As a result, the increase in electricity generation in West Virginia, Utah, and North Dakota is not solely influenced by their respective populations but is also significantly impacted by electricity transfers to neighboring regions. These observations underscore the notion that while population growth contributes to the escalating electricity demand across the U.S., the pivotal driving factor tends to differ from one state to another.

We also examined the environmental consequences of mitigation and socioeconomic development. Fig. 4 illustrates the projected changes in CO2 intensity (million metric tons/EJ) from electricity generation relative to 2015 for each state. CO2 intensity refers to the ratio of CO2 emissions from the electricity sector to the amount of electricity generated. As can be observed, the CO2 intensity of electricity

generation is expected to decrease over time across all scenarios. However, the rate and pattern of such decrease are heterogeneous across all states. Renewable energies are prioritized in states in the Mountain (i. e., Wyoming), Midwest (i.e., Missouri), and South (i.e., Texas) regions and limited in the Atlantic (i.e., New York) and Pacific regions (i.e., Washington). States characterized by a significant proportion of coal- fired electricity generation, such as Wyoming and West Virginia, are projected to experience significant reductions in the CO2 intensity of their electricity generation. This trend is especially prominent when considering scenarios characterized by low emissions. Anticipated de- clines of approximately -233 and -240 million metric tons/EJ on average by 2080, in comparison to the year 2015, are attributed to the combined impact of retiring coal-fired power generation and the adop- tion of renewable energy sources. Conversely, states like South Dakota, which already embrace a substantial share of renewable energy (with over 80% of its electricity generated from renewables in 2021 [47]), face a more constrained potential for further enhancing their CO2 in- tensity performance. Projections suggest a comparatively narrower scope for improvement, with an average anticipated reduction of approximately -50 million metric tons/EJ by 2080 relative to the reference year of 2015, as outlined in scenarios with low emissions. Texas, on the other hand, exhibits an intriguing dynamic, while it ex- periences a significant reduction in CO2 intensity, with an average reduction of roughly -102 million metric tons/EJ by 2080, it also faces a notable increase in water withdrawal. This dual trend underscores the intricate challenges and trade-offs involved in transitioning to a low-carbon energy framework. It exemplifies how states must carefully balance environmental considerations, such as CO2 emissions, with other critical resources like water. These contrasting outcomes empha- size the distinct capacities of each state to navigate the complex tran- sition toward a low-carbon energy framework.

We also investigated the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) under low emission scenarios in comparison to that of under the "Stated Pol- icies" and the "Announced Pledges" [48] (Fig. 5a). LCOE is a measure of the average net present cost of electricity generation for a generator over its lifetime [49]. It includes initial capital investment, operational and maintenance costs, and expected energy output. It has been widely used to compare various forms of electricity production for investment de- cisions. The "Stated Policies" scenario assumes current policies and implementing measures will continue without additional efforts, considering adopted policies, proposals, and yet-to-be-developed mea- sures. In contrast, the "Announced Pledges" scenario assumes the suc- cessful implementation of government commitments and targets under the Paris Agreement, including Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and net zero goals [48]. Recognizing this, our study contributes valuable insights to comprehend the broader implications of the U.S. net-zero goal.

Conclusion Previous research has primarily centered on global and national climate objectives, with less emphasis on how RCP-SSP pathways influence the sub-national electricity sector. Our study addresses this gap by analyzing how climate change mitigation and socioeconomic development interact in the U.S. electric power sector at the state level. The analysis delves into the effects on electricity generation, electricity water withdrawal and consumption, CO2 intensity, and levelized cost of electricity (LOCE) at the state level. The underlying mechanisms that drive the heterogeneous responses at the state level are also examined. Several key conclusions can be drawn from this study.

First, expanding end-use electrification in the building and industry sectors not only facilitates the attainment of mitigation objectives but also catalyzes a surge in electricity generation. This surge is enabled by a rapid growth of natural gas utilization in conjunction with renewable energy sources. Population growth is the primary catalyst behind the surges in most states. In states where the industry sector is the dominant end-user, the interplay between population and electricity dynamics is comparatively subdued. This underscores the importance of understanding end-use electricity for gauging future electricity demand, considering diverse patterns and electrification potential at the state level.

Second, sustainable electricity generation requires balancing multiple considerations, including emissions, environmental conservation, and economic viability [53]. Our low emission scenarios notably reduce water withdrawals, aligning with resource conservation. This shift is propelled by technological advancements, more efficient water cooling, and the embrace of renewable energy sources. Despite the decrease in water withdrawals, water consumption increases. Diverse impacts of mitigation on electricity water use are evident, resulting in increased water withdrawals for certain states (i.e., Texas) while causing reductions for others (i.e., Florida). In our low emission scenarios, renewable energies are prioritized in states in the Mountain (i.e., Wyoming), Midwest (i.e., Missouri), and South (i.e., Texas) regions and limited in the Atlantic (i.e., New York) and Pacific regions (i.e., Washington). Substantial CO2 reduction is achieved, though accompanied by an increased Levelized Cost of Electricity (LCOE), particularly in the eastern states. However, the combined efforts still fall short of achieving the collective commitments under the Paris Agreement. This underscores the importance of managing the balance between water resources, mitigation efforts, and economic feasibility at the state level.

Overall, this research underscores the complexity of reconciling climate mitigation objectives with local electricity demand and resource constraints. It highlights the need for nuanced, state-specific strategies that balance emissions reduction, electricity demand, and water usage. Despite significant research on global and national future pathways, there is a need for further exploration into the application of Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) and Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) to understand sub-national impacts on the electric power sector. This study employs the Global Change Analysis Model (GCAM-USA) to analyze how climate change mitigation and socioeconomic development interact in the U.S. electric power sector at the state level. We developed four scenarios covering different levels of decarbonization efforts and socioeconomic development. Our research findings reveal a prevailing trend towards a less carbon-intensive U.S. electric sector, propelled by an expanding presence of natural gas and renewable energies in the energy mix. Such capital turnover leads to a significant reduction of overall CO2 emissions from the electric sector, albeit at a higher lifetime cost in particularly eastern states. The mitigation efforts also lead to overall decreased water withdrawal and increased water consumption in the electric sector, however, disparities in state-level responses are observed. While population growth predominantly shapes electricity generation, unique state-level electrification potential yields indirect population-electricity dynamics. The spatially heterogeneous response suggests complex trade-offs associated with reconciling climate mitigation objectives with local electricity demand and resource con-straints. In sum, this research equips policymakers and stakeholders with invaluable insights to formulate mitigation strategies that align with the objective of the U.S. electric sector, both at a national and international level, while also catering to the unique characteristics of each state. ## Introduction The electric power sector is a significant contributor to climate change as it accounts for 38% of the greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions globally [1] and 25% in the U.S. in 2021 [2]. Policies and strategies have been proposed and implemented at the international [3] and national levels [4] to reduce GHG emissions from the electric power sector. The Clean Air Act (CAA) serves as the primary basis for federal regulation of GHG emissions in the U.S., in which the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) works with states to reduce GHG emissions [5]. Despite several setbacks in climate mitigation initiatives [6,7], the U.S. rejoined the Paris Agreement and set an ambitious goal of economy-wide net-zero emissions by 2050, including a 65% reduction by 2030 [8]. Also, the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 will bring substantial changes to the power sector, aligning with climate goals and reinforcing energy security. This legislation will reshape energy policies, promoting adaptations for economic stability, inflation reduction, and sector resilience. These changes will lead to transformative measures, prioritizing sustainable energy practices while addressing both eco- nomic and environmental concerns [4]. The success of achieving national climate mitigation targets relies heavily on the implementation of effective sub-national climate actions [9]. States employ a variety of programs to reduce their GHG emissions, such as climate action plans, mandatory GHG reporting, voluntary GHG reporting, and reduction programs [10]. Significant progress has already been made at the state level, with the current state and local GHG actions projected to reduce economy-wide emissions by 25% below the 2005 level by 2030 [9]. As of 2022, 25 states and territories have set GHG reduction targets, with some committing to achieving 100% clean energy goals by 2050 or earlier [11] through renewable portfolio standards, energy efficiency standards, and carbon pricing mechanisms. Therefore, developing sub-national strategies for the power sector in alignment with a national mitigation target is a complex task, particularly when socioeconomic factors are expected to shift and impact power demand. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has devel-oped Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) and Shared So-cioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) to explore different combinations of greenhouse gas emissions and socioeconomic trends [13,14]. Combining these scenarios allows for the examination of potential barriers and opportunities for climate mitigation and adaptation across a wide range of plausible futures. Additionally, the integrated assessment modeling (IAM) approach is widely employed to evaluate the viability of mitiga-tion strategies. IAMs have been extensively utilized in a large body of research to evaluate the effectiveness of various mitigation strategies across scales [15-19]. These models are particularly relevant for poli-cymakers as they provide insights into the trade-offs between different mitigation strategies and the potential costs and benefits associated with their implementation. DeAngelo et al. [20] analyzed 177 global IAM scenarios with different warming levels and found that achieving 1.5 °C resulted in lower energy use, earlier net zero, and less electrification because of the shorter transition time, while greater than 2 °C produced more residual emissions and bioenergy use with regional disparities. McJeon et al. [21] found that with a below 2 °C global temperature objective, global coal consumption decreases by mid-century, and nat-ural gas consumption increases when carbon capture and storage is available and decreases when it is not. Zapata et al. [22] analyzed the impact of climate change on the energy system focusing on four renewable sources and found that while there were small climate im-pacts on renewable primary energy use globally, these impacts led to a decrease in fossil fuel use due to increase in renewables use for most regions, especially in North America. Fragkos et al. [23] explored low-emission scenarios for eleven countries and concluded that emission reductions are achieved through the uptake of renewable energy, energy efficiency improvements, and electrification of energy services. More-over, Khan et al. [24] investigated the impacts of temperature changes on the electricity sector within a scenario aligned with SSP2 and RCP 8.5. They found that Cooling Degree Hours (CDH) increased while Heating Degree Hours (HDH) decreased from 2015 to 2100, with sig-nificant state-level variations. For example, annual mean CDH increased by 30% in Arizona to 170% in Wyoming, and mean HDH decreased by 13% in Florida to 45% in Arizona. Such variations highlight the het-erogeneous impacts of temperature changes on electric sector capacity and investment requirements across the U.S. Burleyson et al. [25] assessed building electricity consumption responses in the western U.S. using two models, BEND and GCAM-USA, under combinations of sce-narios for radiative forcing (RCP4.5 & 8.5) and population change (SSP3 & 5). Despite structural differences, both models demonstrated similar responses, emphasizing the more significant impact of population change and also identified an increase in total building electricity con-sumption under the RCP8.5 scenario in certain states, while others remained largely unaffected. Kebede et al. [26] explored climate change impacts by integrating a global scenario framework, RCP-SSP-SPA, assessing how global pathways manifest as sub-national impacts in three deltas across West Africa and South Asia. Their integrated multi-scale (combined top-down and bottom-up) hybrid scenario approach, combining expert-based and participatory (joint expert-stakeholder) methods, emphasizes the significance of such approaches in address-ing uncertainty in adaptation decision-making, underlining its trans-ferability to other sub-national socio-ecological settings with multi-scale challenges. While prior research primarily concentrated on evaluating the viability and consequences of diverse low-emission trajectories, like those outlined in the RCPs, for meeting global and national climate objectives, it is equally imperative to investigate how the RCP-SSP pathways on a global scale manifest as impacts on electricity sectors at the sub-national level. While sub-national actions have been shown to be effective in reducing emissions and supporting U.S. national efforts [9, 12], there are fewer subnational-level studies that analyze how top-down policies or targets impact the electric power sector at the state level. Hence, our study seeks to enhance comprehension of the interre- lation between top-down climate change mitigation and socioeconomic progress (e.g., population and GDP) in shaping the U.S. electric power sector at the state level. By analyzing the potential impact of different socioeconomic pathways on state level electricity and environmental consequences (e.g., water, CO2 emissions, etc.), we can gain insights into aligning sub-national mitigation strategies in the electricity sector with national and global mitigation goals. Methods We used the global change analysis model, USA version (GCAM-USA), which is an integrated assessment model developed to explore the dynamics of the coupled human-earth system and its response to global changes [27,28]. GCAM consists of five interconnected systems (energy, water, agriculture and land use, economy, and climate), running in 5-year intervals until 2100 [28]. GCAM has been widely employed in numerous studies to evaluate the potential impacts of different policy assumptions and socioeconomic factors on future conditions at national and international scales, such as the 4th and 5th IPCC assessment reports [14,29-32]. GCAM employs external data files containing assumptions about key drivers such as population, GDP, policies, etc., to estimate their implications on crucial outputs like GHG emissions, energy production, and water consumption. GCAM simulates the substitution of high-carbon technologies with low-carbon alternatives based on factors like costs, emissions constraints, and carbon prices. It can also simulate various mitigation actions, including carbon capture, electric vehicles, and more (Table S1). The energy system framework of GCAM encompasses resource production, energy transformation, final energy carriers, and end-use sectors (Fig. S1). The GCAM-USA model provides higher spatial detail, including 50 states plus the District of Columbia. The electricity generation sector within GCAM-USA offers greater detail compared to GCAM, including sub-annual load profiles, US-specific power sector technology costs, state-specific retirements of coal and nuclear plants, and grid region trading. This enables GCAM-USA to investigate mitigation and adaptation of the energy system at the state level, such as exploring state-level power sector capacity expansion pathways [33], electric vehicle deployment for U.S. [34], and environmental co-benefits of low-carbon pathways with state-level resolution [35]. A detailed description of water and power sector modeling in GCAM-USA is available in the Supplementary Material. In this study, we employed GCAM-USA v5.4 and explored four future scenarios for the U.S. that are in line with the global RCPs and SSPs pathways (Table 1). We selected RCP2.6, RCP6.0, SSP3, and SSP5 and created four scenarios by combining the RCPs and SSPs. The RCP-SSP scenarios are relevant in the global context. Our 'RCP-SSP equivalent' scenarios suggest that the conditions of these RCP-SSP scenarios in the U.S. context correspond to those outlined in the global scenarios. In the U.S. context, this translates to a 58% of CO2 emission reduction in 2050 relative to 2015 and zero emission around 2070. Conversely, RCP6.0 depicts a stabilization scenario where GHG emissions peak around 2080, leading to a continuous warming trend and a 3–4 °C global temperature increase by 2100 [30]. In the U.S. context, this is described by continuous growth in CO2 emissions with a peak projected to occur around the year 2095. It is worth noting that RCP6.0 is the reference scenario in GCAM. Incorporating both scenarios enables us to assess a wider array of potential outcomes. SSP3 embodies a "regional rivalry" scenario characterized by high challenges in mitigation and adaptation, prioritizing national and regional security over global cooperation. Industrialized countries experience slow economic growth and low population growth while developing countries face high population growth. In the U.S. context, population growth is projected to be low, with a slight decrease in the second half of the century. Population stabilizes around 267.5 million in 2100 (Fig. S2). In contrast, SSP5 portrays a "Fossil fuel Development" scenario with high challenges in mitigation but low challenges in adaptation. It envisions rapid global economic growth and the exploitation of fossil fuel resources to achieve socioeconomic development goals [36,37]. In the U.S. context, under the SSP5 scenario, the population is projected to steadily increase to 674.2 million by 2100 (Fig. S2). While a warming climate (i.e., RCP6.0) contributes to an increase in climate extremes (e.g., droughts, floods, wildfires, etc.), delving into their intricate details surpasses the capacity of an aggregated model like GCAM-USA. ## Results and discussion As shown in Fig. 1, electricity demand is projected to increase under High population/GDP scenarios, with greater increases when mitigation is present. Mitigation leads to more end-use electrification, particularly in the industry and transportation sectors (Fig. S3) because of the aggressive push towards economy-wide decarbonization. In the Low population/GDP scenarios, a slight decrease in the second half of the century is observed, following the trajectories of the population in these scenarios (Fig. S2). This shows that electricity demand is strongly influenced by population trajectory. The share of renewables in the U.S. electric generation mix has been increasing in recent years, growing from 9.4% to 21.5% between 2000 and 2022 [38], and this trend is expected to continue due to ongoing advancements in renewable energy technologies, decreasing costs of renewables, growing public and political support for clean energy, and the implementation of state and federal policies (i.e., New Source and Performance Standards, the Investment Tax Credit, and the Production Tax credit) in incentivizing renewable energy (including wind, solar, biomass, geothermal, and hydro) deployment. Our results (Fig. 1) confirm a general growth in low-carbon energy sources' shares (including renewables and nuclear) with a more pronounced increase under low emission scenarios. In the reference scenarios with low and high population/GDP, we observe a 122 % and 573 % increase from 2020 to 2100, respectively. In the low emission scenarios with low and high population/GDP, the increase is even more substantial, reaching 313 % and an impressive 1120 %, respectively. The share of renewables and fossil fuels with carbon capture and storage (CCS) also increases substantially in low emission scenarios. This highlights the necessity of CCS for achieving aggressive mitigation targets by 2100. Notably, without mitigation, the share of natural gas increases by 79 % and 330 % from 2020 to 2100 with low and high population/GDP, respectively. This shows that in the absence of mitigation efforts, this cleaner and cheaper source of fuel is expected to meet most of the growing demand for electricity. Nevertheless, it's crucial to acknowledge that such a significant surge in the natural gas share could lead to concerns regarding the sustainability of natural gas resources and the potential for their depletion. This, in turn, could result in higher prices and consequential environmental impacts. Contrary to the general increasing trend in electricity generation across all scenarios, the implications on water withdrawals and con- sumption for the electricity sector are more complex. A low value close to zero (whether positive or negative) indicates that population growth is the primary driver behind increases in electricity generation. A larger positive value suggests that factors other than population are influencing the observed growth of electricity generation. As can be seen in Fig. 3, the results illustrate heterogeneous responses at the state level. The largest electricity user in most states is the building sector (Fig. S8), whose electricity demand is a direct reflection of population. Therefore, the elasticity indicators for most states are close to 0 and electricity generation grows with population growth. However, in the case of Wyoming, the elasticity indicator is significantly greater than 0.3. This is attributed to Wyoming's relatively small population base [41] and the industry sector being the most significant consumer of electricity within the state (Fig. S8). End-use electrification of the industry sector leads to the increase in electricity generation in Wyoming, a pattern not notably swayed by the state's population dynamics. Similarly, Nebraska's electricity generation is influenced by various factors beyond population growth. Nebraska exhibits high per capita electricity consumption, an energy-intensive industrial sector, and significant energy demands resulting from extreme weather conditions, including hot summers and harsh winters [42]. These combined factors create Nebraska's energy profile, highlighting that population is just one aspect of its multifaceted energy generation equation. For Montana, the surge in electricity generation is influenced by the end-use electrification of the transportation sector. The state has the highest number of vehicles per person [43], and electrification of the transportation sector will lead to greater demand for electricity. Additionally, both West Virginia and Utah are net suppliers of electricity to the regional grid and are among the top states in interstate transfers of electricity [44,45]. Likewise, North Dakota follows a similar pattern, with about two-thirds of its generated power being transmitted to other states and Canada through the regional electric grid [46]. As a result, the increase in electricity generation in West Virginia, Utah, and North Dakota is not solely influenced by their respective populations but is also significantly impacted by electricity transfers to neighboring regions. These observations underscore the notion that while population growth contributes to the escalating electricity demand across the U.S., the pivotal driving factor tends to differ from one state to another. We also examined the environmental consequences of mitigation and socioeconomic development. Fig. 4 illustrates the projected changes in CO2 intensity (million metric tons/EJ) from electricity generation relative to 2015 for each state. CO2 intensity refers to the ratio of CO2 emissions from the electricity sector to the amount of electricity generated. As can be observed, the CO2 intensity of electricity generation is expected to decrease over time across all scenarios. However, the rate and pattern of such decrease are heterogeneous across all states. Renewable energies are prioritized in states in the Mountain (i. e., Wyoming), Midwest (i.e., Missouri), and South (i.e., Texas) regions and limited in the Atlantic (i.e., New York) and Pacific regions (i.e., Washington). States characterized by a significant proportion of coal- fired electricity generation, such as Wyoming and West Virginia, are projected to experience significant reductions in the CO2 intensity of their electricity generation. This trend is especially prominent when considering scenarios characterized by low emissions. Anticipated de- clines of approximately -233 and -240 million metric tons/EJ on average by 2080, in comparison to the year 2015, are attributed to the combined impact of retiring coal-fired power generation and the adop- tion of renewable energy sources. Conversely, states like South Dakota, which already embrace a substantial share of renewable energy (with over 80% of its electricity generated from renewables in 2021 [47]), face a more constrained potential for further enhancing their CO2 in- tensity performance. Projections suggest a comparatively narrower scope for improvement, with an average anticipated reduction of approximately -50 million metric tons/EJ by 2080 relative to the reference year of 2015, as outlined in scenarios with low emissions. Texas, on the other hand, exhibits an intriguing dynamic, while it ex- periences a significant reduction in CO2 intensity, with an average reduction of roughly -102 million metric tons/EJ by 2080, it also faces a notable increase in water withdrawal. This dual trend underscores the intricate challenges and trade-offs involved in transitioning to a low-carbon energy framework. It exemplifies how states must carefully balance environmental considerations, such as CO2 emissions, with other critical resources like water. These contrasting outcomes empha- size the distinct capacities of each state to navigate the complex tran- sition toward a low-carbon energy framework. We also investigated the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) under low emission scenarios in comparison to that of under the "Stated Pol- icies" and the "Announced Pledges" [48] (Fig. 5a). LCOE is a measure of the average net present cost of electricity generation for a generator over its lifetime [49]. It includes initial capital investment, operational and maintenance costs, and expected energy output. It has been widely used to compare various forms of electricity production for investment de- cisions. The "Stated Policies" scenario assumes current policies and implementing measures will continue without additional efforts, considering adopted policies, proposals, and yet-to-be-developed mea- sures. In contrast, the "Announced Pledges" scenario assumes the suc- cessful implementation of government commitments and targets under the Paris Agreement, including Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and net zero goals [48]. Conclusion Previous research has primarily centered on global and national climate objectives, with less emphasis on how RCP-SSP pathways influence the sub-national electricity sector. Our study addresses this gap by analyzing how climate change mitigation and socioeconomic development interact in the U.S. electric power sector at the state level. The analysis delves into the effects on electricity generation, electricity water withdrawal and consumption, CO2 intensity, and levelized cost of electricity (LOCE) at the state level. The underlying mechanisms that drive the heterogeneous responses at the state level are also examined. Several key conclusions can be drawn from this study. First, expanding end-use electrification in the building and industry sectors not only facilitates the attainment of mitigation objectives but also catalyzes a surge in electricity generation. This surge is enabled by a rapid growth of natural gas utilization in conjunction with renewable energy sources. Population growth is the primary catalyst behind the surges in most states. In states where the industry sector is the dominant end-user, the interplay between population and electricity dynamics is comparatively subdued. This underscores the importance of understanding end-use electricity for gauging future electricity demand, considering diverse patterns and electrification potential at the state level. Second, sustainable electricity generation requires balancing multiple considerations, including emissions, environmental conservation, and economic viability [53]. Our low emission scenarios notably reduce water withdrawals, aligning with resource conservation. This shift is propelled by technological advancements, more efficient water cooling, and the embrace of renewable energy sources. Despite the decrease in water withdrawals, water consumption increases. Diverse impacts of mitigation on electricity water use are evident, resulting in increased water withdrawals for certain states (i.e., Texas) while causing reductions for others (i.e., Florida). In our low emission scenarios, renewable energies are prioritized in states in the Mountain (i.e., Wyoming), Midwest (i.e., Missouri), and South (i.e., Texas) regions and limited in the Atlantic (i.e., New York) and Pacific regions (i.e., Washington). Substantial CO2 reduction is achieved, though accompanied by an increased Levelized Cost of Electricity (LCOE), particularly in the eastern states. However, the combined efforts still fall short of achieving the collective commitments under the Paris Agreement. This underscores the importance of managing the balance between water resources, mitigation efforts, and economic feasibility at the state level. Overall, this research underscores the complexity of reconciling climate mitigation objectives with local electricity demand and resource constraints. It highlights the need for nuanced, state-specific strategies that balance emissions reduction, electricity demand, and water usage.
